docs.lead_paragraph: The bus terminal in Weirton, W.Va., used to be for people who were going places. These days it is a diner where no one goes anywhere.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Republicans inch away from their plan to reshape Medicare, their equally transformative ideas for Medicaid, now largely in the shadows of the budget debate, are moving front and center.

docs.lead_paragraph: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo -- both professors at M.I.T. -- have helped changed the practice of economics. Mr. Banerjee and Ms. Duflo have pushed anti-poverty programs in developing countries to become more serious about evaluating whether they are actually improving people's lives.

headline.main: Using Economics to Help the World's Poor

docs.abstract: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, economists at M.I.T., discuss their new book, "Poor Economics."
docs.snippet: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, economists at M.I.T., discuss their new book, "Poor Economics."

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazingly, proposals to cap federal spending at something like its recent historical average as a share of GDP still seem to be getting serious attention. The linked report, from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, explains carefully just how unrealistic this is. But I thought I could add a bit with a broad-brush approach.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Jonathan Chait and Jamelle Bouie note, today was another VSP day at the Washington Post, with both the editorial page and the fact-checker tut-tutting at Democrats who insist on describing the Republican plan to dismantle Medicare as a plan to dismantle Medicare.
